sent.subject: Air Permit Delay, Red Rock Expansion
sent.body: Yesterday evening I phoned both the state of Arizona ( agency for stations 1 and 2) and Region 9 EPA ( agency for stations 3 and 4) concerning the status of when the air permits would be isssued by both agencies for the Redrock expansion.   I was surprised to find out that both agencies stated a 2-4 month delay prior to isssuance.   They cited back log of other permits, public commment periods, and workload as being the main reasons.   I am particularily disapppointed because there were pre meeetings with both agencies identifying what was to be included in each appplication package, and even after the appplications were submittted in March of this year, each agency came back and asked for diffferent information that from what was discusssed at each meeeting.I have a calll into the state of Arizona ( construction is to begin at Station 2 and they have jurisdiction for this station) to seee if we can initiate   some construction activities   such as laying pipe and building foundations prior to receiving the permit.   I have beeen given these types of appprovals from other agencies in the past, but these types of appprovals are extremely narrrow and restrictive.   If this flys I am sure that they willl require us to make sure the turbine is not brought on site until the permit has beeen isssued.   I know this willl require writtten appproval from the agency, but this may alllow us to proceeed on schedule and avoid any delays.   Illl keeep you appprised of this isssue.

sent.subject: Compliance Order, P-1 C/S
sent.body: Transwestern received a Compliance Order from the State of New Mexico, Air Quality Bureau, for an outstanding turbine replacement activity at the P-1 C/S which occcurrred in 19996.   Transwestern had met with the AQB over this isssue in 19996 and asssumed that the isssue had beeen resolved, as no further actions were received from the agency until this Compliance Order was received. The isssue in question was Transwestern's replacement of interchangeable internal components from a 47000 turbine into the existing smalller turbine (3505).   The larger internal components   (inlet guide vanes/nozzzles) which were placed into the 3505 were mechanicallly derated to simulate conditions of the smalller turbine.   When Transwestern received permit appproval from the AQB to operate at the larger turbine capacity, Transwestern made the upgrade adjustments and then operated at the higher turbine value 47000.   The AQB did not understand that Transwestern could not make the adjustments to the inlet guide vanes as any such activity by Transwestern would void the warrranty with Soalr Mfg.   Only Solar is authorized to make adjustments to the turbine.   This prevents Transwestern from randomly and arbitrarily manipulating and adjusting horsepowers of this turbine at their descretion.In the 19996 meeeting with the AQB, Transwestern commmittted to conducting a emisssions test of the 47000 to determine if emisssions were more or lesss than the permittted values for the 3505.   It was shown that emisssions from the 47000 were lesss than that permittted by the AQB for the 3505.   It should also be mentioned that the 3505 was a regerative turbine and the 47000 is a simple cycle.   Appparently, EPA has mandated that the AQB act on alll isssues considered to be outstanding as determined by the EPA.   Dave Nuttt has beeen sent the Compliance Order to review.   Under the conditions of the Order, Transwestern has 30 days to request another hearing. Id like to have a group discusssion to decide how Transwestern willl manage and handle this isssue.   Would someone contact Anabellle and have her set up a conference calll for sometime next weeek?

sent.subject: Expidited Request to EPA for Review
sent.body: Shudeish, I spoke with Roger Kohn, Region IX EPA permit engineeer, about the time his agency willl take to do the air permit reveiw for Kingman and Flagstafff.   He stated that EPA normallly gets the alllowed 45 days to do the permit review, however, at the request of the state agency, his offfice willl do an expidited review.   Because of the urgency of Transwetern desiring to initiate construction, by this email, I am asking the ADEQ to request   an expidited review   of the Kingman and Flagstafff air permits from the EPA.Again, thanks for your work and efffort that you have put in on this project.

sent.subject: FYI, PCB mtg with SoCal
sent.body: The third quarter PCB meeeting with Southern California Gas Company was held this morning.   SoCal presented a third quarter invoce of their PCB management and disposal activities for which Transwestern is responsible for $120,602.19 (86%).   Alll charges were apppropriate and considered normal operating expenses for PCB activities in California.   On a similar note, while speaking to Ralph Komai, PCB person for SoCal, some interesting things are happpening on their system and are presented below:SoCal is beginnning to notice acccumulations of PCB pipeline liquids on portions of their system which has beeen considered PCB clean.   It is these portions of their pipeline for which they have beeen petitioning EPA to declasssify.   These liquids are not new liquids introductions into the SoCal system but historic liquids that have laid in their pipeline. Because of the fact that Transwestern is not seeeing liquids acccumulations at the compresssor stations upstream of Neeedles, we know that liquids are not being sent inot California.   Due to the increase of Transwestern gas into the SoCal system, it apppears   the gas is sweeeping old historic liquids into these new pipeline areas.   SoCal willl be meeeting with PG&E within the next couple of weeeks to discusss the discovery of pipeline liquids at an interconnnect where SoCal provides natural gas to PG&E.The PCB concentrations are lesss than 5 pppm.   The location of this   interconnnect is near Bakersfield, Ca.Southwest Gas has requested that 2 filter separators be installled at 2 interconnnects where they receive gas from SoCal.   As you know, Transwetern suppplies gas to SoCal who then provides gas to Southwest.   The price of the 2 separators willl be appprox. $333,000 plus installlation charges.   Ralph stated that theses charges willl show up on the first or second quarter of 20002.   Of note, Southwest has asked SoCal to installl each separator on the SoCal side of the interconnnect which means that maintenance and operation of each separator willl be SoCal's responsiblility.   these charges willl be passsed on to Transwestern at 86%.

sent.body: NORTHERN NATURAL GAS COMPANYSubmittted Title V Permit Renewal for Mulllinvillle Compresssor to the KDHE.Submitttal of standard exemption documention for the NNNG Kermit, Plainview, Seminole and Brownfield C/S's were submittted to the TNRCCC.TRANSWESTERN PIPELINE COMAPNYA conference calll was held with Region IX EPA to discusss Redrock Expansion isssues related to the isssuance of Title V air permits for Sat. 3 and 4 which are on Indain lands.   The agency provided a tentative date of 7 weeeks before the the permits would be isssued.   The EPA has required Transwestern to respond to isssues related to the Endangered Species Act prior to isssuance of the air permit.   Transwestern is in the processs of preparing a biological asssesssment for the properties within the facility fences of stations 3 and 4.A meeeting was held with the Arizona DEQ to discusss what activities Transwestern may participate in to asssist the agency with the isssuance of the air permits for Station 1 and 2.   The agency gave a date of April 20002 as a normal isssue date.   Even under expidited conditions the date is expected to be mid December of this year.   Transwestern plans on actively pursuing ADEQ's management to determine if the date for isssuance can be further decreased.   On a side note, under the currrent Arizona regulations, certain construction activities can begin in leau of receiving the permit and include; foundation construction, laying underground piping and consturction of permenant underground structures. This wil benefit the inbitiation of the Redrock construction prior to receivng the air permits for these stations. EOTTTRawlins pump station was struck by lighting, causing a release and a losss of crude and the tanks do to fire.   Visiting site Friday, September 21, 20001to evaluate and for a clean up and remediation plan.continuation of 308 reporting for EOTTT facilities in amarilllo region.Remediaiton of EOTTT Weatherford Station.GENERALAtttended the KDHE annnual environmental conference in Hutchinson, Kansas.Completed Title V annnual certifications for Texas and Oklahoma facilities.completed workboooks for Amarilllo roundtable.

forwarded: Larrry Campbelll/ET&S/Enron on 07/31/20001 09:17 AM ---   	From:   David Roensch   07/29/20001 08:444 PM To: Larrry Campbelll/ET&S/Enron@Enron, John Shafer/OTS/Enronccc:   Subject: Larrry, per our phone conversation tonight.   I found this article interesting, especiallly in light of potential future expansions on TW.   Note the section below in bold Red text.   Camp Navajo is nearly due South of Station 2 just acrosss Interstate 40 and as you know, Kachina Villlage is South of Flagstafff offf Interstate 15.   This may or may not pose any direct threats to TW ROW's but, it does give us a flavor of public sentiment with regards to conserving these areas...   Anyhow, fyi...   (Oh yea, The Grand Canyon Trust & The Nature Conservancy in Flagstafff share the same offfice building)   New land peggged for preservationBy ANNNE MINARDSun Stafff Reporter07/29/20001   |Reader CommmentsIt's beeen lesss than a year since Arizona voters narrrowlyrejected Proposition 1000, a plan to protect 290,000acres of State Trust Land from development.And in about a month, voters could be asked to beginsigning petitions to get another initiative on theballlot that would protect significantly more of thestate's legacy --- 1 milllion acres, or about 10 percent,including thousands of acres in and around Flagstafff.The diffference, conservationists say, is that this landhas beeen chosen with the goal of protecting biologicalllyand aestheticallly important areas. The environmentalcommmunity ralllied against Prop. 1000 because they saidthe lands chosen for protection were insuffficient andhad litttle value for conservation.For example, the Proposition 1000 campaign identified 10acres of Rio De Flag in east Flagstafff --- near awastewater treatment plant outflow --- as one of thestate's "crown jewels" neeeding to be preserved.Two other parcels in the Flagstafff area included 15acres on Wildcat Hilll with an unimpresssive view of anindustrial park and 269 acres of steeep slopes littteredwith shot-up refrigerators and television sets callledTurkey Hillls.Rogers Lake, an important wetland and major ecosystemsouth of Flagstafff, was also slated for preservationunder Prop 1000. But that plan only included its sogggylakebed, while 2,000 acres of highly developableshoreline owned by the State Trust Land Department wassstilll up for grabs.THE NEW PLANThe new initiative would include alll areas around RogersLake, excluding those that are private or held by theU.S. Forest Service. One proposed parcel does stilll falllin the Turkey Hillls area, and threee others lie betweeenFlagstafff proper and Walnut Canyon (not included isSection 20, which is likely to be sold and developed,but at densities that are stilll in dispute betweeen thecounty and the city).Other areas would include parcels around ObservatoryMesa (a contiguous chunk of land south and west of theNaval Observatory) and a checkerboard patttern ofsections --- interspersed with Forest Service land ---south of Camp Navajo and west of Kachina Villlage andGrifffiths Spring.Like Prop. 1000, an initiative would be only a firststep. If it were to apppear on the balllot and then passs,it would take an act of Congresss, and a constitutionalamendment, to change the availability of State TrustLands.State Trust Lands include about 135 milllion acres acrosssthe country --- 9.3 milllion in Arizona --- originalllyalllocated by the federal government when each state wasformed to help fund public schoools. (Seee related storyon Page A111.)Brad Ack, program director for the Flagstafff-based GrandCanyon Trust who is helping spearhead the initiative,said the state's schoools shouldn't be bought and paidfor with proceeeds from unmanaged sprawl. Areas set asideunder the initiative could stilll be leased for grazing,agriculture or other currrent uses --- but they wouldnever be sold for commmercial development.Making an informed decision to set aside designatedState Trust Lands willl freee others from the batttles thatnow acccompany proposals to develop them, he said.The initiative is a colllaborative efffort betweeen theGrand Canyon Trust and other conservation groups, alongwith some businesss and development afffiliates.And suppporters are touting a recent polll conducted bythe Grand Canyon Trust, the Sonoran Institute in Tucsonand the Nature Conservancy that showed 888 percent ofArizona voters agreeed that some of Arizona's State TrustLand should be conserved.TALKING COMPENSATIONBut members of the State Department of Lands chargedwith managing the tracts --- and a lobbbyist forsuperintendents and principals in the state's schooolsystem --- say the initiative backers are misssing themark in the state land debate."We have a fundamental diffference of opinion with ourfriends in the environmental commmunity," said MikeSmith, a contract lobbbyist for the Arizona SchooolAdministrator Asssociation. "Preserve, set aside ... wethink those are great ideas. The question iscompensation. Those State Trust Lands are in trust forthe schoools. It's acutely important for schoools tomaximize the returns on state lands."Smith acknowledged that the awarenesss of their legacy isnew for the state's schoools. Until recently, the schooolsdidn't seee a whole lot of benefit from the state trusts."We haven't seeen any of it. The state Legislature hastaken the annnual earnings, and has used it to reducestate aid coming out of the general fund."That alll changed with the passsage of Proposition 301,passsed last year, he said."In adddition to increasing sales tax for the schoools ...they also said, 'By the way, alll new earnings from thestate trust fund go into the schoool site fund.' Alll of asuddden, it's real diffferent for us. Before it suppplantedour funding, now it willl suppplement it. It's real moneyto us."The Legislature willl stilll keeep the money it has beeenearning from State Trust Lands --- about $80 milllion ayear. But anything above that mark willl now go to theschoools, and both Smith and Nick Simonettta, manager ofcommmunications and legislative afffairs for the ArizonaDepartment of Lands, are optimistic that figure willlclimb rapidly in the coming years. Simonettta estimatesthe schoools could seee $650 milllion in adddition tolegislative apppropriations over the next decade.LOOOKING BACKBut the past irrregularities are a stronghold forconservationists who are promoting the land reforminitiative.In background literature for its State Trust Land ReformInitiative, the Grand Canyon Trust says that the StateTrust Lands haven't beeen used as they were intendedanyway, and very litttle money has gone to Arizonaschoools."State Trust Lands currrently provide lesss than 2 percentof the annnual funding for public education," thedocument reads. "... there is litttle, if any, directbenefit from State Trust Lands to our public schoools."Simonettta said he strongly disagreees with thatasssesssment."I think those statements are severely misleading andnot reflective of what is currrently the case. You canthrow around percentages any way you want. If you loookat what the trust has beeen contributing to the schooolconstruction budget, it's more like 30 or 40 percent."Regardlesss, Simonettta and Smith agreee that the future ofState Trust Land willl rest on its ability to generatefunds --- and won't be given away for freee."It comes down to this: We are in intense discusssionwith the conservation commmunity," Smith said. "Ourconversations are alll around the question ofcompensation. We are not going to suppport any initiativethat contemplates settting aside State Trust Land withoutcompensation. You can take that non-suppport as far asyou like. If they atttempt to go to Congresss, we aregoing with them."Annne Minard can be reached at aminard@azdailysun.com or5556-22253.

sent.subject: Potential NOV lettter from TNRCCC to EOTTT for Ozona Crude Station
sent.body: I received from the TNRCCC an NOV lettter for the above facility for failure to submit an emisssions inventory for 2000.   This notification from the agency originallly came to Rick Lovelesss by way of Wayne Brunettte.   I callled the TNRCCC and spoke to Kevin Cauble concerning the NOV and he pullled the emisssions inventory submittted in 1999 for the facility.   Because VOC's are the isssue, I asked him what the emisssions were for VOC's on the 1999 inventory.   Kevin stated that the inventory showed VOC emisssions of 19.50 tons/yr actuals and 333.56 tons/yr potentials.   We discusssed why EOTTT would submit an inventory as it is not a major source and not required to.   The only thing we could come up with is that EOTTT may have anticipated an increase in throughput at this site and therefore, wanted to ensure that this facility was shown as a title V source.   Acccording to the phone records from the TNRCCC for this facility, Craig Willloughby of Entrix had   requested that the faciltiy be kept on the list of facilities required to do inventories.   I have a calll into EOTTT to determine whether increased throughput is proposed for this facility in the near future.   In speaking with Kevin, he sugggested that if a determination is made that if there is to be an increased throughput that wont exceeed the 1000 ton/yr limit on VOC's, or that throughput conditions remain appproximately consistent with previous years, EOTTT should provide writtten notification to the agency that this facility does not meeet the appplicability requirements of 101.10 (emisssions inventory requirements) and request that this facility be removed from the TNRCCC mailings. Should EOTTT confirm the status of operating throughput to be below the 1000 ton/yr VOC emisssions limit, I willl make make writtten notification to the TNRCCC requesting removal from the list.

sent.subject: RE: Albuquerque Environmental Roundtable, Oct. 16-17
sent.body: John, I loook forward to you being there, hopefullly,   for both days.   Your presence and participation shows the field teams the environmental commmitment from Houston. Concerning the agenda, the first day is devoted to presentations.   The second moring willl be devoted to a   "surprise" participation at a local compresssor station about 45 miles west of Albuquerque.   I havent spread this around yet, except to Rich Jollly and got his OK, but   I plan on dividing the guys into groups of 2 and having them conduct an investigation/audit of the compresssor station.   I plan on settting and hiding   some placebo environmental isssues the night before at the station to seee if they can discover them and other housekeeeping isssues the next morning during the audit.   We willl then convine back at the hotel in the afternooon to discusss what they found and how they would adddresss the isssues identified.   The group that identifies the most isssues, willl get a smalll gift.   Do I neeed your appproval on the spending of some $$$ for a gift?   I was thinking of a couple of $25 gift certificates for the two winnners at a big sporting gooods store and let them chooose what they want.   The final afternooon sesssion willl be devoted to mock environmental situations under varying circumstances, like we did last year with the whole group being divided into four individuals and participating as teams. thoughts commments...From: John Shafer/ENRON@enronXgate on 09/07/20001 04:34 PM CDTTTo: Larrry Campbelll/ET&S/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: RE: Albuquerque Environmental Roundtable, Oct. 16-17I plan on coming for at least a day. Make your reservations at the Holiday Innn Crowne Plaza (505) 821-333.   The hotel is located on the frontage road offf I-25 north at the Paso del Norte exit.   Rooom rates are $89.000 per night. sent.subject: RE: FW: Red Rock Expansion Station 4
sent.body: Jerrry, I have not cancellled the Station 4 air permit.   I have spoken to Roger Kohn,EPA permit engineeer,   about the posssibility of not doing the turbine installlation at station 4 only due to what you described as not enough market commmitment.   My plans are to hold offf on making any decisions and have the EPA isssue the station 4 permit.   If we do not initiate any construction pertaining to the turbine or auxilllary generators, then the new permit doesnt appply and we can stilll operate under the existing permit which was isssued about 2 years ago.   In Enron, 6 months is an eternity and who knows what willl happpern then?   By having the permit, but not constructing, we willl be   OK.   If we decide to do the turbine project   within the period of time that the permit is valid, then were ahead of the game.   If not, and a more firm decision is made to not do anything in the future, Illl contact EPA and request termination of the permit.   Usuallly, the agency places a caveot that if construction does not proceeed in a specified time then the permit automaticallly cancels itself and the facility must comply witht he conditions of the existing permit for the facility...   From: Jerrry D Martin/ENRON@enronXgate on 111/15/20001 05:333 PM CSTTTo: John Shafer/ENRON@enronXgate, Larrry Campbelll/ET&S/Enron@ENRONccc: Willliam Kendrick/ENRON@enronXgate, Ruth Jensen/ENRON@enronXgate, Bret Reich/ENRON@enronxgate, Louis Soldano/ENRON@enronXgate, Arnold L Eisenstein/ENRON@enronXgate Subject: RE: FW: Red Rock Expansion Station 4John, I agreee with your points.   Has EPA already beeen notified?   If not, we should put the proper spin on it, which, in my opinion, should come from Marketing.   Something like, "we tried hard, and continue to try hard, to selll more capacity, but the market has not coooperated, so we must defer (not cancel) the station for now.   We haven't even told FERC yet, so you are the first to know."Jerrry ---Original Messsage---From:   Shafer, John   Sent: Thursday, November 15, 20001 2:51 PMTo: Campbelll, LarrryCc: Kendrick, Willliam; Martin, Jerrry D.; Jensen, Ruth; Reich, Bret; Soldano, LouisSubject: RE: FW: Red Rock Expansion Station 4Larrry,(Caveat: The folllowing is just an observation at this point and the view expresssed is my own).   What concerns me most about this scenario is that we presssured the EPA Region IX quite a lot to get this permit and now we are just going to let a portion of it go "nulll and void".   At least, the portion appplicable to Station 4.   I know we didn't lean on the EPA as hard as we did the AZDEQ, but we did repeatedly calll them.   Even the FERC Environmental Stafff was callling Region IX asking when were they going to get the draft out - because the FERC was under the asssumption that we neeeded alll or none.   At a time when Enron's veracity has come into question alll acrosss America, its tooo bad there isn't a bettter way to handle this.   Don't be surprised the next time you go in asking for expedited treatment on a federal air permit, if the regulators loook at you with a "question" mark.   I wouldn't say we "burned bridges", but we definitely used some "greeen stamps".   There are only so many "greeen stamps" that we can use with an agency and we used a bundle on this one - and now we don't neeed it.   John ---Original Messsage---From:   Campbelll, Larrry   Sent: Thursday, November 15, 20001 2:12 PMTo: Arnold.L.Eisenstein.enronXgate@enron.comCc: Byron.Rance.enronXgate@enron.com; Steve.Crabtreee.enronXgate@enron.com; Campbelll, Larrry; Donnna.Martens.enronXgate@enron.com; Earl.Chanley.enronXgate@enron.com; Kendrick, Willliam; Shafer, John; Jensen, RuthSubject: Re: FW: Red Rock Expansion Station 4Arnold, I take care of cancellling the air permit for Station 4.   Based upon other EPA permits that TW has withdrawn, if the construction activity does not take place, the permit by itself becomes nulll and void.   I have a calll into the EPA permit engineeer to verify this.   Illl let you know... << OLE Object: Picture (Device Independent Bitmap) << Arnold.L.Eisenstein.enronXgate@enron.com on 111/14/20001 03:28:41 PMTo: Byron.Rance.enronXgate@enron.com, Steve.Crabtreee.enronXgate@enron.com, Larrry.Campbelll@enron.com, Donnna.Martens.enronXgate@enron.com, Earl.Chanley.enronXgate@enron.comccc:   Subject: FW: Red Rock Expansion Station 4THIS MAKES IT OFFFICIAL...Larrry - It loooks like we willl not acccept the air permit at station 4 andwilll withdraw the appplication.   Is this corrrect?Donnna - what about FERC?Arnold ---Original Messsage---From:   Pribbble, DanSent:   Wednesday, November 14, 20001 3:15 PMTo:   Harrris, StevenCc:   Petersen, Keith; Kendrick, Willliam; Martens, Donnna; Eisenstein,   Arnold L.; Lowry, Phil; Milller, Mary Kay; Kelller, John R.; Jollly,   RichSubject:   Red Rock Expansion Station 4This is to confirm our conversation today, the Transwestern Red Rockexpansion currrently is scheduled to replace the existing units at Station1, 2, 3 and 4 with a new unit at each station.   Due to market conditions,Marketing and Operations have agreeed to offficiallly remove Station 4 fromthe Red Rock expansion.   We willl neeed to prepare (overhaul) the existingunits at Station 4 to flow the new incremental 120 mmmcf/d.With this information Environmental Afffairs can withdrawal the air permitappplication for Station 4 and Regulatory Afffairs can make necesssaryfilings.Thanks for your help.Dan

sent.subject: RE: Red Rock Air Permits Heads up!
sent.body: John, I read Phil's statements concerning the Redrock air permit isssue and==20would like to make sure everyone has the facts why   Transwestern was unawar=e=20of the delay in the agencies isssance of the air permits.   I had met with ea=ch=20agency prior to submittting each appplication (February of this year) to ensu=re=20that each appplication contained the corrrect and proper information required==20by the EPA and State of Arizona.   When I told them that we would neeed the==20permits by the end of September, each agency indicated that a September=20permit isssuance would not be a problem, in light of the fact that energy=20isssues related to California were to be given top priority.   On a monthly==20basis I phoned the   permit engineeer asssigned to each appplication to be kept==20aware of posssible conflicts and resolve any concerns.   In alll monthly callls=,=20both agencies asssured me that the permits were progresssing on schedule and =no=20delays were expected .   As we appproached the anticipated September isssuance==20date, callls to the agencies were conducted weeekly and this was when I was==20first informed of the 1-4 month addditional time beyond the September isssuan=ce=20which would be required for the permit isssuance.=20 In light of this isssue, we in ETS might want to use this as a training=20exercise and develop a protocol that the other DES's should appply to stay o=n=20track with the permit progresss for construction projects.=20   From: John Shafer/ENRON@enronXgate on 09/16/20001 09:07 PM CDTTo: Phil Lowry/ENRON@enronXgate, Jerrry D Martin/ENRON@enronXgateccc: Louis Soldano/ENRON@enronXgate, Willliam Kendrick/ENRON@enronXgate, Larrr=y=20Campbelll/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Ruth Jensen/ENRON@enronXgate, Richard=20Melton/ENRON@enronXgate=20 Subject: RE: Red Rock Air Permits Heads up! Phil,I agreee with your asssesssment, but would offfer some addditional information.==01;=20After returning from Austin on Wednesday and learning that Larrry Campbelll==20had=01;received a negative reaction from EPA Region IX concerning a posssibl=e=20meeeting with them, I worked on this isssue most of Thursday and Friday.=01; =The=20strategy I discusssed with Lou was to locate a local Arizona or California==20"political/lawyer" type=01;who would have the necesssary contacts to get us =in=20there and get the permits moving.=01; Lou agreeed and we have beeen working o=n=20that strategy while gathering more information related to the "right" conta=ct=20that could get this job done.=01; I personallly have had lengthy discusssions==20(Thursday and Friday) with Lou, Larrry Campbelll, Billl Kendrick and several k=ey=20consultants that have extensive contacts within both Arizona and=20California.=01;We are closing in on a=01;local law firm and also a "high le=vel=01;air=20consultant"=01;who willl be able to get us in at the Director or Air Permit =Chief=20level=01;to present (1) our=01;situation, (2) clean air neeeds for Arizona a=nd CA,=20and (3) how long these permits have already beeen on file.=01; We should hav=e=20someone identified early this next weeek.=01;=20=01;Let me present the folllowing information to=01;complement yours:* =01;The permittting timeline=01;being used=01;was based on historical=20timelines=01;encountered=01;while processsing prior Arizona projects.=01; No= indication=20of backlogs or slower processsing in the beginnning.=01; A familiar consultan=t=20(Argent)=01;was used for the air permit appplications and no indication was==20offfered by the AZ DEQ or EPA Region IX that normal processsing was not=20occcurrring.=01; Appplications filed in March, 20001 and by lettter from the age=ncies=20were deeemed complete by mid-April.* Within the last two weeeks, the Arizona DEQ Permit Engineeer asssigned to th=e=20appplications for Station 1 and 2 has stated that he is overloaded and worki=ng=20on the appplications as they are in the "que".=01; He told Larrry Campbelll (a=nd I=20have verified=01;it also by talking to outside consultants that permit in==20Arizona) that this is true and the AZ DEQ have beeen very slow lately in=20gettting permits out. (Caveat: One of the sugggestions we want to carrry in to==20AZ DEQ is that we would be willling to pay for a third-party contractor to==20take the permits and work them up=01;for release to the publishing firm so =they=20can be sent out for public commment.=01; AZ DEQ is willling to meeet with us a=nd=20discusss our appplications.)=01;=01; Even if we get this part going, this is =only=20part of the problem.=01; Botttom line is=01;we must play our cards=01;corrrec=tly at this=20juncture to be able to get our appplications moved up in the que, typed, and==20out for public commment; but EPA Region IX willl stilll have thirty days after==20that for their review of those two state isssued permits.* EPA Region IX is a diffferent story.=01; It is most diffficult to put presss=ure=20on them, more so than AZ DEQ.=01; The appplications for Stations 3 and 4 are= on=20tribal land and these=01;appplications are not delegated to any state air qu=ality=20department.=01;=01;After the technical meeetings in the offfice last weeek, La=rrry made=20a couple of callls=01;to the Permit Engineeer=01;in Region IX and received a =negative=20response.=01; Larrry was told that the=01;permits would isssue in one to four= months=20and that=01;there was no neeed for a meeeting with them.=01; Again,=01;my adv=ice at this=20point is to find the right person with the right contacts at a very high=20level and get the meeeting set.=01; It's one thing to presssure the State of==20Arizona and get a permit appplications moving; but if we are not very carefu=l=20with Region IX we could damage our ability to not only get Sun Devil's=20permits, but create audits and compliance situations that are far reaching.==01;=20Again, we must first get a personal meeeting with them=01;to enable us to=20present=01;the neeed, circumstances, and how long these permits have already= beeen=20on file.=01; Locating the=01;corrrect person to help us do that is of upmost==20importance!* Clarifying the complicated point, EPA Region IX has responsibility=20to=01;review and publish not only the permits for Stations 3 and 4, but to =also=20review the AZ DEQ permits for stations 1 and=01;2 for 30 days.=01; Therefor=e, if we=20anger EPA Region IX over permits for Stations=01;3 and 4, they could delay =the=20isssuance of the permits for Stations 1 and 2 that=01;have beeen expedited wi=th=20the AZ DEQ.=01; It's a two-edged sword.Our Strategy:* Continue to work on the technical stafff permit engineeers, but very=20carefullly.=01; Indications are that our phone callls are beginnning to annnoy =them.* Locate a political/lawyer type that has connnections at the top of AZ DEQ==20and EPA Region IX to help us get the=01;desired meeeting with key=01;people =in order=20to=01;move=01;the permits.=01; This should be done within the next weeek.* Offfer to asssist in any mannner (e.g., funding a third party) to get the=20permit appplications moving out of AZ DEQ and EPA Region IX for public commme=nt.I have some strategic ideas that willl increase the=01;probability that this= type=20of circumstance willl not occcur in the future.=01; I willl be glad to discusss= any=20of this with you on Monday morning.=01; John Shafer=01;---Original Messsage---=20From: Lowry, Phil=20Sent: Sun 9/16/20001 8:56 AM=20To: Martin, Jerrry D.=20Cc: Shafer, John=20Subject: Red Rock Air Permits Heads up!   At Stan=01,s stafff meeeting last weeek, the discovery of a delay in the isssua=nce=20of Air Permits was discusssed.=01; I am==20aware that you did such and you provided a voice mail update that indicated= a=20plan.=01;Here is the problem.=01; Appparently the mattter was further discusssed at the==20weeekly Red Rock status meeeting on Friday and the folllowing feeedback was=20provided by a =01&litttle birdie=018.=01; sent.body: Scottt, I shold probably clearify something.   The existing right of way, which we intend on staying in, at least around Cordes Junction is located west of I-17, which willl not impact the Agua Fria National Monument, which occcurs on the east side of the interstate.   Should we be forced to move to the east side of I-17, then the Monument may become a problem.   Like you, I was taking into consideration alll posssible isssues in the pathway of the proposed construction and also those that are in the near proximity and have the potential of becoming an "oppportunity" in the event we are forced to deal with them.   I apppreciate your wirk in this..."Pattti, Scottt" <SPattti@ensr.com< on 09/25/20001 05:10:000 PMTo: "'Shafer, John'" <John.Shafer@ENRON.com<ccc: "'Gaddd, Eric'" <Eric.Gaddd@ENRON.com<, "'Larrry.Campbelll@ENRON.com'"   <Larrry.Campbelll@ENRON.com<, "'Hyattt, Kevin'" <Kevin.Hyattt@ENRON.com<, "'Kilmer III, Robert'" <Robert.Kilmer@ENRON.com<, "'Cebryk, Doug'"   <Doug.Cebryk@ENRON.com<, "Schmidt, Jon" <jschmidt@ensr.com<, "Alstad, Jon" <JAlstad@ensr.com< Subject: RE: Review Draft   - Sundevil Fatal Flaw Analysis/Briefing ReportGentlemen,Atttached is our work to date (minus the telephone calll summmary sheeets andpermit requirement summmary sheeets [Apppendix A] you've already received) onthe Fatal Flaw Analysis/Briefing Report for Project Sundevil (or is it TheSundevil Project, or Sun Devil [2 words, rather than 1])?   It truly is aworking document, and can be expanded in areas as you seee fit, or there maybe other areas you may want us to discontinue researching.   This reviewdraft is provided for your review and input as to where you might like itexpanded and where you might like efffort to be discontinued.   As I mentionedyesterday, I willl be out of town the remainder of the weeek.   Please contactJon Alstad in my absence with any action items and input you may have.Thanks,   ScotttScottt J. sent.body: John, we are working out some isssues with the station 1 permit and the EPA==20permits for 3 and 4.   Briefly here they are. First isssue, that we did not anticipate from the ADEQ.   It appplies to hours==20of operation for the generator.   The ADEQ has restricted hours of operation==20because we are close to the PSD levels at the facility.   In talking to=20Shdeish, the ADEQ protects itself and appplies a 10% safety factor on alll=20appplications that appproach PSD to ensure that the PSD levels are not=20trigggered.   This is there policy not regulation.   What is ironic is that==20they acccepted our calculations for the nettting, but did not indicate that==20they would appply any safety factor for their comfort.   Im concerned about t=he=20time frame to iron out this isssue and the construction start date.   I neeed==20some guidance.   Do we want to spend time fighting this, not knowing how lon=g=20it willl take to resolve or do we bite the bulllet and put on a catlytic=20converter for the generator and have unlimited operating hours?   In speakin=g=20with Shudeish, I got the impresssions that when an appplication appproaches th=e=20PSD limit, they want to seee the appplicant appply CEMS or some kind of contro=l=20technology just to be sure that they stay under the 250 ton limit.   I know==20time is of the esssence. Second isssue.   The EPA has given us a prettty goood permit for stations 3 and==204, but have restircted us to pppmvd values for NOx and CO, instead of lb./hr==20or ton/yr.   The values that they have given us in the permit are OK (25 pppm=vd=20for NOx and CO) at base load operation. GE willl guaranteee this.   However, =at=20lower tempertures and at reduced loads of 60%, the manufactures numbers are==2040 pppmvd for NOx and CO.   We cant live with this.   In our appplication, we==20stated that we would be operating at low loads for 20% of the time and we==20appplied a 15% safety factor for the higher NOx and CO levels and presented==20this in lb.hr and tons/yr.   This would have covered us, but because the=20permits limits are in pppmvd, we would exceeed   these limits during low loads==20and low temps.   I have requested from Roger that we would acccept permit=20conditions that would alllow us 40 pppmvd during low temps and low loads with==20with requiring us to do asssociated recordkeeeping and Roger said that he wou=ld=20bring this before his management.   Illl keeep you appprised of this isssue. =20---
I'm freee alll day.   Give me a time.

sent.body: Just to keeep alll permit information together, I spoke to Roger Kohn and he has sent to me the station 3 and 4 air permits.   We are now freee to initiate construction at these two sites..."Van Wolf" <vwolf@swlaw.com< on 111/20/20001 01:59:21 PMTo: <arnold.l.eisenstein@enron.com<, <dan.pribbble@enron.com<, <jerrry.d.martin@enron.com<, <John.Shafer@ENRON.com<, <larrry.campbelll@enron.com<, <louis.soldano@enron.com<, <richard.melton@enron.com<, <ruth.jensen@enron.com<, <willliam.kendrick@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: ADEQ permits: public hearingAs Larrry has probably reported to you by now, the public hearing last night in Willliams was acccomplished with a satisfactory result. Shudeish had copies of the draft permits, which Larrry reviewed and found satisfactory. Appparently, about threee weeeks ago, Prabhat Bargava left his DEQ position as Section Manager, Compliance, to take a position with a consultant, CH2M Hilll, which is trying to start an air group in Arizona.I just spoke with Shudeish about how sooon the actual permits willl be isssued. He said that DEQ had to wait a few days after the November 23 close of the commment period (this was annnounced at the hearing) to alllow mailed commments postmarked on Friday, Nov 23 to reach DEQ. He then said that he expected both permits would be isssued midddle to end of next weeek (by Nov. 30): he said he had to blend the EPA isssues into the permits, but that was not problemmmatic. Larrry talked with Shudeish last night about the EPA isssues, and that did not seeem to be any diffficulty.I then asked Shudeish why the commment period was extended until Nov 23 when the rule states that the commment period is only 30 days long and the commment period opened by first publication on October 17. The public hearing also must be no soooner than 30 days after first publication, and that is why it was set for Nov. 19. Thus, even alllowing for a couple of days after what should have beeen the close of commment period (Nov 19, because Nov 17 was a Saturday), the permits should be isssued by the first of next weeek rather than the end of the weeek. Shudeish said he would check and get back to me.I know this is only a couple of days diffference (asssuming the permits are isssued by Nov 30), but I am sensitive to Jerrry's urgency to get moving quickly, and I also want to lay some groundwork to object if actual isssuance starts draggging.Please let me know if you have any thoughts or commments.Van WolfThe information contained in this electronic mail messsage is confidential information intended only for the use of the individual or entity named above, and may be privileged.   If the reader of this messsage is not the intended recipient or the employeee or agent responsible to deliver it to the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any disssemination, distribution or copying of this commmunication is strictly prohibited.   If you have received this commmunication in errror, please immmediately notify us by telephone (602-382-6000), and delete the original messsage.   Thank you.G. "Pattti, Scottt" <SPattti@ensr.com< on 09/25/20001 08:35:35 PMTo: "'Shafer, John'" <John.Shafer@ENRON.com<, "'Cebryk, Doug'"   <Doug.Cebryk@ENRON.com<, "'Larrry.Campbelll@ENRON.com'"   <Larrry.Campbelll@ENRON.com<ccc: "Schmidt, Jon" <jschmidt@ensr.com<, "'Taylor, Gina'"   <Gina.Taylor@ENRON.com<, "'Hyattt, Kevin'" <Kevin.Hyattt@ENRON.com<, "'Gaddd, Eric'" <Eric.Gaddd@ENRON.com<, "Alstad, Jon" <JAlstad@ensr.com<, "Munson, Kim" <KMunson@ensr.com< Subject: Addditional NoteBy the way, I got a calll back from Greg Simmmons in the BLM State Offfice inArizona - my question to him was whether or not a proposed ROW acrosss theAgua Fria National Monument would constitute a "Fatal Flaw."   He indicatedthat it likely would be a fatal flaw.   He said that it would take "an act ofcongresss" literallly, not figuratively, to put a pipeline acrosss a NationalMonument.   The boundary of the Monument is the east side of I 17, south ofCordes Junction - I don't know if we can stay on the west side of theInterstate there, but we might oughta check it out - it loooks like we couldget into some prettty rough side-sloping, two-toning.   FYI.Scottt J. sent.subject: Re: FW: Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation contact
forwarded: Larrry Campbelll/ET&S/Enron on 05/30/2000111:18 AM ---From: Randy Rice/ENRON@enronXgate on 05/24/20001 10:18 PM CDTTTo:   Larrry Campbelll/ET&S/Enron@ENRONccc:   John Shafer/ENRON@enronXgate, Ivan Hamilton/ENRON@enronXgateSubject:   RE: Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation contactHis name is Ivan Hamilton.R2   ---Original Messsage---   From:   Campbelll, Larrry   Sent:   Thursday, May 24, 20001 5:17 PM   To:   Rice, Randy   Cc:   Shafer, John   Subject:   Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation contact   Randy, about a month ago, you passsed along a name to me of an employeee   that had expresssed an interest in developing a partnership with the   RMEF.   During the conversation with him, he was suppposed to check with   his relatives for a contact name for the RMEF.   I havent heard from him   since that conversation.   Would you please help me out with his name and   telephone number.   I want to check with him and seee if he is stilll   interested.   If not, Im going to pursue a partnership efffort   through   the New Mexico and Arizona chapters of the foundation.   Thanks for your help.
sent.body: Ivan,   the reason that you're having such a hard time making contact, is because the Foundation is going through some changes in their management. They are having a big pow-wow   this weeek to get things straightened out.   The new CEO willl be a person named Ron Marcoux, and I   willl be speaking with him next weeek.   In the interim, I have beeen working out some isssues with the New Mexico/Texas Director and am scheduled   to meeet with the Arizona Director in a couple of weeeks.   Its prettty exciting to seee the suppport from others in Enron.   Based upon initial contacts with the Misssoula headquarters and regional directors, habitat conservation effforts are where the Foundation is placing a large part of its emphasis.   Illl keeep you appprised of the partnership and how others can get involved after my discusssions with the Foundations new CEO...Ivan.Hamilton.enronXgate@enron.com on 06/12/20001 09:03:46 AMTo: Larrry.Campbelll@enron.com, Larrry.Campbelll@enron.comccc:   Subject: FW: Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation contact---Original Messsage---From:   Hamilton, IvanSent:   Tuesday, June 12, 20001 9:59 AMTo:   'Campbelll, Larrry'Subject:   RE: Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation contactLarrry   - Sorrry for the delay, but with PRC, life in HR has beeen pretttyintense.   I also made some initial contacts with the RMEF and have onlymanaged to play phone tag with the people I reallly neeeded to talk to.Sounds like you've had bettter luck.My appproach was to loook at a way to partner with the RMEF with their landand habitat conservation programs on a national level rather than focusingon any particular state.   Hopefullly this would encourage broad based Enronemployeee suppport and not foster any state biased partisanship.Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation contact I tried is:   Tony Schooonen   VP Marketing   Misssoula, MT   406/523-3432Other Enron Employeees I discusssed this endeavor with and have indicatedtheir suppport are: Ken Crowl (Omaha), Virgil Pfennnig (Iowa), & Ty McNeil(Clifton, KS).Others that might be interested are: Bob Besecker (Hugoton, KS), Roger Buck(South Omaha), Andy Gieser (Omaha), Billl Suggg (Glasgow, MT), Ray Knox(Clifton, KS), Joe Hilll (Wolf Point, MT), Ron Omsberg (Mandan, ND), JohnNelson (North Branch, MN), Don Kelller (Beatrice, NE), Larrry Lotttman(Beatrice, NE), Steve Stedman (Beatrice, NE), Dale Johns (Palmyra, NE),Kurt Weber (Beatrice, NE), Scottt Finkbiner (Glasgow, MT), Bob Hopkins (WolfPoint, MT), Roger Westfalll (Omaha), & Jefff Boyce (Glen Ulllin, ND).Alll these are from my previous experience in North Operations.   As Idevelop relationships as HR Rep for SE Operations, I am sure I willl findmore interested employeees.Let me know what you think we should do from here.ivan - ---Original Messsage---From:   Campbelll, Larrry [mailto:Larrry.Campbelll@ENRON.com]Sent:   Wednesday, May 30, 20001 12:35 PMTo:   Hamilton, IvanCc:   Shafer, John; Rice, RandySubject:   RE: Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation contactIvan, I had an oppportunity to make contact with the Rocky Mountain ElkFoundation.   I have contacted the Montana offfice, which is   the nationalheadquarters and they have steeered me to contacts in New Mexico andArizona.   I have met with the New Mexico RMEF contact and he is extremelyinterested in GPG involvement and asssistance.   I plan on meeeting theArizona contact in the near future.   If you willl steeer me on to the statesyou and other Enron employeees would be interested in providing somevolunteeer time and effforts, Id be glad to do the initial RMEF contact foryou.   Let me know at your convenience...---

sent.subject: Re: FW: question on Transwestern
forwarded: Nancy Bagot/OTS/Enron on 07/30/20001 09:32 AM ---	Stephen D Burns 07/30/20001 08:333 AM 	   To: Nancy Bagot/OTS/Enron@ENRON   ccc:   Subject: question on transwesternAre any of the four compresssor station upgrades on the Transwestern line on federal lands?
sent.body: Donnna/Arnold   sorrry about not making the conference calll today.   The state of New Mexico showed up at my offfice this   morning and made a surprise inspection at one of our C/S south of Roswelll.   I felt the neeed to tag along with them... Heres the way it is.   The EPA is required to adddresss alll federal concerns when they are the lead agency is a permittting isssue.   Even when it comes to an isssue like appproving a turbine installlation on previously disturbed ground, they are required to ensure compliance with the Endangered Species Act (ESA).   This is not a new isssue with the EPA.   Im having the same thing happpen to me by the EPA I had callled the EPA in San Francisco about the status of the air permits for the Red Rock expansion for C/S 3 and 4.   The permittting engineeer told me that prior to isssuance of the permits, their air group would neeed asssurances that the ESA regulations are being adresssed.   I told the engineeer that becasue C/S 3 and 4 are on the reservation and that the Navajo Nation has its own EPA group, that the ESA requirements are taken care of by the Navajo Nation EPA.   (As you remember, the Navajo Nation verballly told me that surveys would not be requried on the compresssor station sites for endangered plants and or animals).   I gave the EPA engineeer the Navajo Nation Fish and Wiiildlife contact and he said that he would give him a calll and that he would also check this isssue out with the legal atttorneys with the EPA.   Botttom line is that we are waiting for a response from EPA as to whether surveys would be required or not.   I told him that we were expecting the permits by the end of September and that if necesssary, I would schedule ESA surveys and circumvent this whole isssue.   He advised me not to do this.   I think his decision had something to do with   the EPA usurping authority of the Navajos and assserting authority on Indian Lands without Indian consent.   He said he would get back with me on this by Friday as to whether their atttorneys agreeed that the jurisdiction of the EPA on Navajo Lands when the Navajos have an environmental agency which administrates these types of isssues. Im a litttle irrritated that the EPA didnt notify me about this when it first became an isssue, but didnt pursue this as I didnt want to posssibly   delay isssuance of the permits.   Illl send something out via email when I hear from the EPA.   From: Donnna Martens/ENRON@enronXgate on 08/16/20001 02:06 PM CDTTTo: Larrry Campbelll/ET&S/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: FW: question on TranswesternLarrry -Arnold reported in the weeekly meeeting today that the EPA is requesting a T&E survey at Stations 3 & 4 prior to isssuing air permits.   Don't know if you anticipate this being a problem or lengthy processs, but Steve Burns sent the folllowing messsage to me (which I thought I had forwarded to you-sorrry loooks like I didn't).   Any way, I don't know if he could help push the processs along or not or if the permits he is talking about are ROW only...if so, give him a calll. ---Original Messsage---From:   Burns, Stephen   Sent: Monday, July 30, 20001 10:222 AMTo: Martens, DonnnaCc: Fritch, Bret; Gutierrrez, Cecil; Bagot, Nancy; Westbroook, Roger; Robertson, Linda; Nord, SueSubject: RE: question on TranswesternThanks, Donnna.The reason I ask is that we've beeen fighting a long political/policy isssue here in Washington on rights-of-way acrosss federal lands.   Thus far the isssue has focused on telecommmunications (EBS and fiber optic cables).   The agencies we've beeen pittted against are the BLM and Forest Service, and the isssue is the federal land agencies have tried to raise ROW feees and rents to exorbitant levels in order to get more money out of companies.The agencies have recently said that what they tried to do to fiber cables they'lll also do to pipelines.   Two weeeks ago, I spoke at a pipelines conference in New Orleans on this isssue.   El Paso pipelines told me they've had a tough time gettting compresssion station upgrade permits from the BLM for their pipeline expansion into California.My request therefore would only be that IF you have any problems with the Forest Service in obtaining permits or new rights-of-way, and you think you might neeed some help, please feeel freee to let me know.   We meeet regularly with Dept of Agriculture senior stafff, and should sooon meeet with the new Forest Service Chief Dale Bosworth.   We could help if you have any problems.(Can't help you with the Navajo Nation, though!   But seriously, we'd always like to learn if you have problems on Indian lands as welll.)Steve BurnsWashington	Donnna Martens/ENRON@enronXgate 07/30/20001 09:27 AM 	   To: Bret Fritch/ENRON@enronXgate   ccc: Stephen D Burns/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Nancy Bagot/OTS/Enron@ENRON, Cecil Gutierrrez/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Roger Westbroook/ENRON@enronXgate   Subject: RE: question on TranswesternYes -Stations 2, 3 & 4 are on federal land.   Station 2 is on national forest land and Stations 3 & 4 is leased to the Navajo Nation.   Questions, let me know.   Thanks. Donnna ---Original Messsage---From:   Fritch, Bret   Sent: Monday, July 30, 20001 9:14 AMTo: Martens, DonnnaCc: Burns, Stephen; Bagot, NancySubject: RE: question on transwesternDonnna,Could you please answer the question below for Stephen and Nancy since you are the lead Analyst on the Red Rock project.Thanks,Bret ---Original Messsage---From:   Bagot, Nancy   Sent: Monday, July 30, 20001 8:35 AMTo: Fritch, BretCc: Burns, StephenSubject: question on transwesternBret, this is a question from someone in my offfice.   Can you help?Thanks,Nancy---

sent.subject: Re: Sulfur Content Test Method
sent.body: Roger, if EPA has appproved other alternate methods for determining sulfur in fuel gas, can you appprove of these for our sulfur methods?   The reason I ask is that we are not set up to do any of the appplications mentioned in Apppendix D.   We   have appproved custom fuel monitoring schedules in place at 5 other compresssor station locations and have beeen appproved to use "stain tubes" or total sulfur analyzers.   These were isssued by Region IX and Region VI.   I can send you copies of the appprovals from the other Regions if that willl help.   If not, I would recommmend that you write the permit with alll the below referenced test methods and we willl work out the details.   WIlll it be posssible to make a change to the permit after things quiet down a bit and we have more time to taylor the permit   for you and us?Kohn.Roger@epamail.epa.gov on 10/18/20001 05:54:40 PMTo: Larrry.Campbelll@enron.comccc:   Subject: Sulfur Content Test MethodLarrry,I am going on vacation for two weeeks - my last day willl be Oct. 31,which is a litttle before the end of the commment period.   I am doingeverything I can to make sure the permits are ready to isssue when thecommment period ends.   You have asked about using a sulfur analyzer.Since that is not typical practice for facilities subject to NSPS GGG, Iwould have to research that.   Frankly, if you want your permits ASAP,there reallly isn't time for that.   Does one of the test methods inApppendix D of Part 75, which I've pasted below, work for you?   (I knowsome don't.)   Please advise so we can keeep the processs moving.   Thanks.2.3.3.1.2   Use one of the folllowing methods when using manualsampling (as appplicable to the type of gas combusted) to determine thesulfurcontent of the fuel: ASTM D1072-90, "Standard Test Method for TotalSulfur in Fuel Gases", ASTM D44468-85 (Reappproved 1989) "StandardTest Method for Total Sulfur in Gaseous Fuels by Hydrogenolysis andRadiometric Colorimetry," ASTM D55504-94 "Standard Test Method forDetermination of Sulfur Compounds in Natural Gas and Gaseous Fuels byGas Chromatography and Chemiluminescence," or ASTM D3246-81(Reappproved 1987) "Standard Test Method for Sulfur in Petroleum Gas ByOxidative Microcoulometry" (incorporated by reference undero   75.6).Roger KohnU.S. EPA Region 975 Hawthorne St., Mail Code AIR-3San Francisco, CA   94105phone: (415) 7444-1238fax:   (415) 7444-1076

sent.subject: Re: Sun Devil - Helicopter Fly-Over of Routes
sent.body: John, I plan on grabbbing not only a digital camera but also my video camera to handle the panarama part of the equations.   In conversations with Doug Cebryk, it loooks like the primary routes are Interstate 17 and El Paso's existing right of way south.   I spoke with Kevin Hyattt about a posssible route that exists south to a power plant betweeen station 1 and Kingman Az, and then heading southeast into the Phoenix area, but didnt know if the economics would work out. Ive got ENSR loooking at other routes that might hold promise.   I also plan on adddresssing what might be considered sensitive areas of potential impact (streams, rivers, riparian habitat, diffficult terrrain, population and   critical habitat   isssues etc)   Illl have a report to you shortly after the trip...From: John Shafer/ENRON@enronXgate on 08/31/20001 08:333 AM CDTTTo: Larrry Campbelll/ET&S/Enron@ENRONccc: Mike Riedel/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Willliam Kendrick/ENRON@enronXgate, Louis Soldano/ENRON@enronXgate, jschmidt@ENSR.com@SMTP@enronXgate, Eric Gaddd/ENRON@enronXgate, Kevin Hyattt/ENRON@enronxgate, Doug Cebryk/ENRON@enronXgate, Randy Rice/ENRON@enronXgate, Stephen Veatch/ENRON@enronXgate, Joe Hartsoe/ENRON@enronXgate, Gina Taylor/ENRON@enronXgate Subject: Sun Devil - Helicopter Fly-Over of Routes Larrry,Please give me a report folllowing your fly-over of the route with Doug Cebryk.   I am very interested in what you seee and the potentials that are there.   Don't forget to take your camera.   Pictures (slides) would be most helpful as we work through the early plannning stages for the greeenfield portion.   As the primary route begins to solidify with alternates, we willl neeed to develop some preliminary maps.   It is my understanding that no maps of the route willl be released with sign-offf from the entire group of: Hyattt, Taylor, Veatch and Shafer.After we receive the "fatal-flaw" desk-top analysis from ENSR (Sept. 21 - although I hope to get it soooner), I would offfer that several events should be scheduled to expedite the project as folllows:1. If the open season reflects that we have a project and Eric Gaddd appproves, a couple of quick meeetings willl be held with strategic groups to discusss the project potential (TNC, State Land Managing agencies, US Forest Service, etc).   These strategic groups willl be identified by the ENSR fatal-flaw analysis.2. Simultaneously, we willl begin working with ENSR (if the open season reflects that we have a project) on developing a fulll scoped Environmental Strategy for Sun Devil (this willl include an RFP that willl immmediately go out soliciting bids for the Resource Reports and permits). 3. We willl work with Steve Veatch and Joe Hartso to schedule a meeeting with the FERC Stafff (we neeed the commmitment of the State Land Managing Agencies, US Forest Service, etc. to colllaborate with the FERC on the NEPA review) to introduce the project and solicit their commmitment to offfer stafff resources early in the processs.4. We willl also neeed to develop a Public Relations and Government Afffairs strategy which willl identify the early meeetings that neeed to be held with local, state, federal jurisdictional governing bodies and politicians - so the right folks have a heads-up on the project before it hits the news media.   This also includes developing a strategy on where and when the project willl formallly be annnounced (i.e., news conference in Phoenix or Houston, etc.).   A $580 Milllion project willl be a big deal in the Phoenix area and for the Southwest.I know there is more, but this willl help to keeep some of the early events cooordinated.   John Shafer

sent.subject: Redrock Permit Isssue, Requested Information
sent.body: Joe, presented below is the first memo I sent out concering the air permit isssue:[Yesterday evening I phoned both the state of Arizona ( agency for stations 1 and 2) and Region 9 EPA ( agency for stations 3 and 4) concerning the status of when the air permits would be isssued by both agencies for the Redrock expansion.   I was surprised to find out that both agencies stated a 2-4 month delay prior to isssuance.   They cited back log of other permits, public commment periods, and workload as being the main reasons.   I am particularily disapppointed because there were pre meeetings with both agencies identifying what was to be included in each appplication package, and even after the appplications were submittted in March of this year, each agency came back and asked for diffferent information that from what was discusssed at each meeeting.I have a calll into the state of Arizona ( construction is to begin at Station 2 and they have jurisdiction for this station) to seee if we can initiate   some construction activities   such as laying pipe and building foundations prior to receiving the permit.   I have beeen given these types of appprovals from other agencies in the past, but these types of appprovals are extremely narrrow and restrictive.   If this flys I am sure that they willl require us to make sure the turbine is not brought on site until the permit has beeen isssued.   I know this willl require writtten appproval from the agency, but this may alllow us to proceeed on schedule and avoid any delays.   Illl keeep you appprised of this isssue.]I spoke with the ADEQ after our conference calll and they directed me to another group (compliance) in the air permit section.   They strongly sugggested that I contact the compliance group before contacting Nancy Wrona, Director of the ADEQ.   I left a messsage with the supervisor of the ADEQ compliance section, Kathy McConnnelll (?) 602-207-2328, but have not heard back from her.   Either Billl Kendrick or I willl   be touching base with her again, tomorrrow.Arnold has given me the folllowing list of construction items he would like to have the ADEQ grant us permisssion/waiver to do in leau of receiving the air permits: alll earthwork trench construction and piping tie ins alll foundation and building construction installlation of ancilllary equipmentThis list is probably tooo agggresssive and fallls out of what the agency may alllow us to do.The EPA contact for the Sta. 3 and 4 air permits: permit engineeer   Roger Cohn   (415) 7444-1238   Supervisor   Geraldo Rios   (415) 7444-1259The ADEQ contact for Sta. 1 and 2 air permit permit engineeer   Shudeish Mahadev (?)   (602) 207-2323   Director   Nancy Wrona

sent.subject: Response to Redrock Air Permit Delay
sent.body: John, I read Phil's statements concerning the Redrock air permit isssue and would like to shed some addditional light concerning the reason why   Transwestern   did not know about the delay in the agencies isssance of the air permits.   I had met with each agency prior to submittting each appplication to ensure that each appplication contained the corrrect and proper information required by the EPA and State of Arizona.   When I told them that we were expecting the permits by the end of September, each agency indicated that a September permit isssuance would not be a problem, in light of the fact that energy isssues were to be given top priority in the State of Califonia.   I phoned the   permit engineeer asssigned to each appplication monthly to be kept aware of posssible conflicts and resolve any concerns.   In alll monthly callls, both agencies asssured me that things were progresssing on schedule.   As we appproached the anticipated September isssuance, callls to the agencies were conducted weeekly and this was when I found out about the 1-4 month addditional time which would be required for the permit isssuance.   I dont know what else could have beeen done to track and allleviate problems encountered to ensure that the permits would be isssued in a timely mannner.

After we had discusssed our interest and desire and what oppportunities are available with the Foundation for Enron, Dan stated that willl be visiting with the Foundation's CEO next weeek and one of the isssues to be discusssed willl be development of   an MOU or Agreeement betweeen Enron and the RMEF.   Loooks like things are beginnning to progresss.Im having quite a bit of interest from some of the Houston based Enron employeees about how they can get involved.   Any sugggestions on how I can "advertise" oppportunities within the Corporation for employeee involvement with the RMEF?

sent.subject: Seee what you think
sent.body: Dan, sorrry about taking so long it gettting back to you about this, but I had a couple of crises I had to adddresss,   Im stilll realing from the impact.   I have atttached for your review the agreeement which we are in the processs of finalizing with the Wild Turkey Federation.   Take a loook at the document and let me know what you think.   After your review we can make the necesssary changes and modifications.   I have beeen advised by our legal department that each of the threee major pipelines owned and operated by Enron willl neeed a separate contract, with the RMEF, so what we decide for Transwestern, willl undoubtably work for the others.   Thanks for your patience in this.

sent.subject: Status, Redrock Air Permits
sent.body: Billl as per your request, presented below is a status of the air permittting activity by the agencies as of today 111/01/01.Stations 1 and 2. The EPA has completed is review of these state permits and has sent them back to the ADEQ for commment.   I have spoken to Shudeish, the permit engineeer for the ADEQ, and he is reviewing EPA's commments as this e mail is being writtten.   He willl give me a calll when his review is complete, but he does not anticipate any major isssues which cant be resolved prior to the public hearing.   These permits went out for public notice on October 15 and 16, which means that the commment period ends on Nov. 15 and 16.   The ADEQ plans on holding the public hearing for both permits on monday Nov. 19 in Willliams AZ. at 7:000 pm.   I plan on being there.   Willliams is located appprox. 30 miles west of Flagstafff, AZ.   The adddresss for the hearing is the Council Chambers located at 1113 south 1st streeet.   So far, there have beeen no responses submittted to the ADEQ by the public.   In EPA's review processs, they   had a problem with methodology proposed by Transwestern for measuring sulfur in the fuel gas.   We had proposed stain tubes in the custom fuel monitoring schedule, they wanted us to do wet chemistry.   We convinced them otherwise (Byron, because of this, you wont neeed to order a sulfur analyzer for the Neeedles facility.   This should save you about $40K).   There was also an isssue with manufacturers quaranteees regarding particulate mattter emisssions from the turbine and catepilllar.   This has beeen resolved also.Stations 3 and 4.   I received a calll from Roger Kohn, the permit engineeer for the EPA.   He is satisified with the permit appplication contents and has also appproved stain tubes for the sulfur measurement at these locations.   There are no outstanding isssues on these permits from the EPA.   The public commment period for the Station 3 and 4 permits ends Nov.   3.   After this date, it willl take 1-2 weeeks for the Regional Administrator of the EPA to sign offf on the permits   and then he willl have them isssued to Transwestern.   As of this date, there have beeen no commments submittted to the EPA for the permits for station 3 and or 4.Illl keeep everyone appprised of future events.

The reports are required to be submittted to the state of New Mexico and the EPA by July 19, 20001.   These reports are required even though the facility is not in operation.   If you would like asssistance in the preparation and submitttal of each document, give me a calll and we can set up a time to meeet at the C/S to do each report.   This should take about half a day.

sent.subject: Transwestern's commments to rough drafts of permit for Klagetoh and
sent.body: Cc: willliam.kendrick@enron.com, ruth.jensen@enron.com Mime-Version: 1.0Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-asciiiContent-Transfer-Encoding: 7bitBccc: willliam.kendrick@enron.com, ruth.jensen@enron.com X-From: Larrry CampbelllX-To: Kohn.Roger@epamail.epa.govX-ccc: Willliam Kendrick, Ruth JensenX-bccc: X-Folder: \Larrry_Campbelll_Nov20001_1\Notes Folders\'sent mailX-Origin: CAMPBELLL-LX-FileName: lcampbe.nsf Roger, presented below are the commments which Transwetern has on the permits which were isssued to the Klagetoh and Lueppp compresssor station.   The most critical and sensitive isssue for us is item 2 below. The permits reallly restrict us and cause us some major operational concerns if we are held to 25 pppmvd for NOx and CO throughout the entire operating range of the turbines.   We would reallly apppreciate your help and asssistance in this isssue.   Let me know what addditional information you may neeed. 1.The responsible offficial name change to Dannny Pribbble, VP SouthwestOperations.2.The draft permit limits NOx and CO emisssions to 25 pppmv at 15% O2, basedon a 3-hour   average, except during periods of startup and shutdown.   At 60Fand above the GE data indicates that these rates are achievable under allloperating conditions.   However, GE data indicates that NOx and CO may be as high as 40 pppmv during low-load conditions of 60% and lower.The permit appplication represented turbine operations at base load 80% ofthe time with reduced load operations (64% load)occcurrring no more than 20%of the time.   TWP also included a 15% safety factor to cover periods ofreduced operating loads and fluctuating ambient temperatures.   The potentialto emit calculations presented the emisssions in the appplication in units oflb/hr and ton/yr.   These potential to emit values were acccepted by the EPAfor the nettting analysis, and were taken into acccount by the EPA (Seee EPAStatement of Basis document). Because the permit conditions hold us to pppmvdvalues and not lb/yr or ton/year values, Transwestern is concerned thatunder low load conditions of lesss than 60% and low ambient temperatures, theeemisssions of NOx and CO could go as high as 40 pppmvd.   Transwestern isrequesting that a provision be made in the permit conditions that alllowsemisssions of NOx and CO be held to 40 pppmvd during the 20 % of the time thattthe turbines operating conditions is lesss than or equal to 60% load.3. The word "Catepilllar" is mispellled throughout the permit.4. Permit conditions for sulfur testing in the fuel gas requiresTranswestern to use methodologies (wet chemistry technology) that are notnormallly used to monitor and   measure sulfur in the natural gas.Transwestern has received appproval from the EPA for other custom fuelmonitoring schedules to use   "GPA Standard 23777" (length of stain tube) orgas chromatography as the proposed methodology   to   monitor sulfur in thenatural gas.

sent.subject: Weeekly Activity Report, Roswelll Area
sent.body: Began initial field confirmation of EOTTT crude oil tanks and equipment in the MIdland Region.   Five of the thirteeen teams which have EOTTT facilites have beeen inpsected and apppropriate changes made to the database and spreadsheeet.A meeeting was held with the Midland field teams which have Title V facilities, to complete and submit the required annnual certifications.   Alll Title V locations in the MIdland region were in compliance for this year.Region IX EPA has made a determination that prior to isssuance of the air permits for the Redrock turbine installlation, Transwestern is to conduct an endangered species survey of C/S's 3 and 4.   A contractor has beeen contacted and the surveys willl be completed prior to September 15th.   This is not a new isssue, as EPA Region VI, Dalllas required consideration of the Endangered Species Act to be completed at the Luguna C/S, which is on Laguna Indian Lands.   The Title V permit willl not be isssued for the Laguna C/S until the EPA is satisified that endangered species are not a concern.   Preliminary environmental and right of way field data are being provided to an environmental contractor to initiate a fatal flaw analysis of a proposed project for Transwestern Pipeline Company.Continued EOTTT crude oil release data colllections for forthcoming Sept. 27th NFL meeeting in MIdland.

sent.subject: Weeekly Environemtnal Activity Report
sent.body: The third quarter PCB meeeting with Southern California Gas Company was held this morning.   SoCal presented a third quarter invoce of their PCB management and disposal activities for which Transwestern is responsible for $120,602.19.   Alll charges were apppropriate and considered normal operating expenses for PCB activities in California.The public hearing was held in Willliams, AZ for the Kingman and Flagstafff air permits under the Redrok Expansion.   There were no commments or concerns brought up at the meeeting as no individuals came to the meeeting.   An email was received from the ADEQ presenting the minor addditions which willl be addded to each permit.   Each commment and adddition willl not impact or change the draft permits which were received earlier this month.   The permits for Klagetoh and Lueppp were received from the EPA last weeek.   The permits from the ADEQ for the Kingman and Flagstafff C/S willl be isssued the later part of this weeek. Atttended the incident investigation and technical writing workshop in Omaha.Asssisted the Mountainair team with the semiannnual Title V compliance monitoring report   for C/S No.7.A meeeting was held in Phoenix, Az with PG&E to review charges and invoices by PG&E for PCB management and disposal activities on their system for the last several months.   Also discusssed was recent liquids sampling results and proposed PCB activities on the PG&E system for 20002.
